Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back neatly modelled, with main features marked, such as clypeus, prothorax, elytra and humeral callosities; at side, legs reasonably well modelled; underside incised with the name of Padiaset inscribed in hieroglyphs; longitudinally pierced; glaze almost gone, but some traces of pale green tinge; core-pale creamy yellow; surface rather eroded.
Curator's comments: Published in Gorton with the translation Padibastet (Gorton 1996, 129-130, type XXXVI, subtype 10-15, see especially 15 for this specimen, but more likely to pertain to her larger more coherent type XXVIII B), a common name found on Naukratis scarabs (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 117-118; on the various productions of the Scarab Factory, see Webb forthcoming). However, the hieroglyph 'st' is clear and the inscription therefore should be read Padiaset, another popular name during the Late Period in Egypt. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884-5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 116)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 129, Type XXXVI no. 15)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.109) (phase 3)
